Seems to me the 'failed star' criteria is the best cutoff. If it formed from a proto-planetary disk around a star-like object (star, brown dwarf, etc.), it is a planet. If it formed from collapsed from a gas cloud (without a massive central object, such as a star or brown dwarf), and is not a hydrogen-burning star, it's a brown dwarf. Now, one thing that could complicate this is if a proto-planetary disk could be massive enough to potentially produce a star (after a primary star had already fromed), in which case massive gas balls formed in them could also be 'failed stars'.

I actually really like the deuterium and/or lithium criteria because they reflect a different behaviour of the object irrespective of the formation mechanism.  It means the test is dependent on the object itself and not on how it formed, perhaps a very long time ago and distance away.

A presentation like this should present both sides of the ongoing planet debate, not just that of the International Astronomical Union (IAU). The IAU definition was adopted by just four percent of its members, most of whom were not planetary scientists but other types of astronomers, and was rejected by an equal number of planetary scientists in a formal petition. These planetary scientists, some of whom presented their alternate, geophysical planet definition to the Lunar and Planetary Sciences Conference in 2017, reject the notion that an object has to clear its orbit to be a planet and consider dwarf planets to be a subclass of planets--just like dwarf stars are a subclass of stars, and dwarf galaxies are a subclass of galaxies. The geophysical planet definition, which is as scientifically legitimate as the IAU's dynamical definition, defines objects first and foremost by their intrinsic properties rather than by their location. If an object is not a star itself and is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, according to this definition, it is a planet, regardless of whether it orbits a star, orbits another planet, or floats freely in space. https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2017/eposter/1448.pdf

I can't agree with this. A star is defined as an object which either is now, or at some previous point in it's life used to be undergoing fusion as a result of it's mass generating a core temperature high enough for this to occur.

A planet does not do this. A planet is defined as an object massive enough to be round, which has cleared it's neighbourhood, and either is now or at some previous point used to orbit a star.

Both planets and stars can orbit other stars. Both can be found alone in deep space. Both can be formed from the central accretion of a cloud of dust and gas or from the leftovers after a larger object took the central portion away. Both can have high or low "metal" content. I don't see any of the criteria you suggest creating a clean definition.

In my view Brown Dwarfs are not "failed" stars. They are stars because they are undergoing fusion which is the definition of a star.

That way the important category division, what is a star and what is a planet, is clear cut: Fusion=>Star, No Fusion=>Planet.

How you then go on to categorise Brown Dwarfs from other stars is less important and does not need to be so clear cut. Since most stellar categories are defined by a combination of mass and color, for the time being that might be good enough, or we could go with what is being fused.
Now I feel bad for brown dwarfs. Failed dreams always sadden me.

Why do the stars have less metalicity than the planets formed around them?  Objects of different masses fall at the same rates under the acceleration of gravity (in a vacuum).  In a non-vacuum, objects of higher density fall faster than objects of lower density (in general).  It seems that a near-vacuum is appropriate to model this scenario, so we'd expect to see the same or slightly higher metalicity in the star than in the leftover solar system... except I'm apparently wrong, so what gives?

There is a process in which a "failed star" can become a star. The hydrogen burning temperature is much higher than that of deterium, and that's why these stars can burn deuterium but not hydrogen. However, some brown dwarf babies can burn their deuterium and heat up just enough to ignite hydrogen in their core and form a little long lasting red star. Something that's overlooked in the converstation a little bit, what makes sense to people less familiar with astronomy. I think the formation argument is the one which should hold the most weight, because it makes fairly intuative sense to anyone. Planets are things that orbit stars (and formed from their leftovers), whereas something floating in the void like a star but less bright, is a failed star. The only hiccup would be the odd planet without a star at all, which while rare does seem to happen.

Great video, and really makes the case that Pluto (and Ceres, Quaoar, Sedna, Eris ...) are all in fact Planets.  They may be "failed" planets, but they formed in the same way (planetary accretion), have the same properties, and belong in the same category as the others, which should be called "Major Planets" rather than just "Planets."
One way we might distinguish if these are planets or stars is if they can go supernova, wether this is from the dwarf collapsing in on itself or a binary brown dwarf system colliding

In case anyone was confused, "metal" in astronomy terms means any elements and compounds above helium - not just shiny hard chunks of stuff. To astronomers, oxygen, carbon dioxide, nitrogen, water, everything is a metal except for hydrogen and helium. When you look at a planet with an atmosphere, a solid core, maybe some rocks or plenty of gas, there's a lot of stuff that isn't hydrogen and helium, whereas stars have an overwhelming amount of hydrogen and helium.
So how do you know if you're looking at a brown dwarf or a heavily overpopulated humanoid planet if they both look the same to JWST? ;)

The part on mettalicity was wrong. Stars and planets are supposed to have the metallicity, because they formed from the same material. The real distiction is that giant planets are preferentially formed in high metallicity system, because they need to form as a rocky core first (core accretion model), so systems with giant planets are metal-rich (star and planet). Whereas brown dwarfs can be found with all metallicities because they don't follow the same formation mechanism; they form in the same way as stars, and are supposed to have the same metallicity function as stars. As video said, mass is not very useful to define brown dwarfs, because objects in that mass range can be either be the high-mass tail of the planet mass function, or the low-mass tail of stars mass function.

This means, if we find a potential exo-planet that ends up being a BD, then it won't be a planet in that system and the system will be instead considered a multiple star system.  There might be other typical planets in this type of system, but we know that planets in multiple star systems aren't as common or as stable in those systems. But is the controversy only limited to BDs circling other "real" stars, or does it extend to other BD systems as well. After all, ​Scholz’s Star is called a star even if it is BD, and it has another companion that is also a BD. It makes no sense to call either of them planets.

The difference seems obvious to me, but I'm not a tenured professor paid to make things excessively complicated.
1) What does the object orbit?
2) Does it have an atmosphere?
If it orbits a star & has an atmosphere, it's a planet.
If it orbits a star & does NOT have an atmosphere, it's an asteroid.
If it orbits a planet, it's a moon.
If it's not in orbit around either, then it's a comet.

Interestingly, there are observations of objects (which are probably very numerous) sometimes called "sub-brown dwarfs" which are believed to have formed by the same process as stars and brown dwarfs but which do not have enough mass to fuse deuterium. In the extreme cases, these may be less massive than certain gas giants. Since there are also observations of objects believed to have formed as planets and escaped their original star systems ("rogue planets"), it isn't clear how we could ever reliably distinguish between members of these two groups.
